items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible through this afternoon and evening, Saturday 27th November. Water levels are likely to remain higher than usual for the next few days. This is due to weather conditions associated with Storm Arwen. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Sunday 28th November.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: Strong northerly winds associated with Storm Arwen are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Yorkshire Coast from midnight Friday 26th November 2021 to Saturday 27th November 17:00. Hazardous conditions might extend 2 hours either side of the high tide. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around the North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by noon on Saturday 27th November 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Esk catchment
items.message: Tides along the River Esk estuary are expected to be high as a result of the effects from Storm Arwen and rainfall overnight on the Esk catchment during   Saturday 27th November between 08:30 and 13:30. Areas most at risk include Low lying land in the Esk Valley, particularly around Briggswath, Ruswarp and some minor roads. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. You can check flood warnings and alerts on the GOV.UK website or via Floodline number 0345 988 1188. We are monitoring the situation closely. This message will be updated by noon on Saturday 27th November 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Seven catchment
items.message: The flood alert for the River Seven catchment has been issued. River levels have risen in this area as a result of rainfall overnight on Friday 26th November 2021. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected during Saturday 27th November 2021. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. You can check flood warnings and alerts on the GOV.UK website or via Floodline number 0345 988 1188. We are monitoring the situation closely. This message will be updated by noon on Saturday 27th November 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to continue to overtop sea defences as a result of Storm Arwen along the Northumberland Coast. Strong waves and spray are expected throughout the morning and into this afternoon, 27/11/2021. Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  

This message will be updated by 19:00 tonight, 27/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: Strong northerly winds associated with Storm Arwen are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Yorkshire Coast starting from Friday evening, 26th November 2021, from 20:00 until midnight, Saturday 27th November between 07:00 and 13:30, and the evening tide between 19:00 and midnight. Hazardous conditions might extend 2 hours either side of the high tide. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Staithes and Whitby, alongside low lying paths around Whitby Harbour. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by noon on Saturday 27th November 2021, or as the situation changes.
